Title: Prime ideals are maximal if all $r$ satisfy $\,r^{n_r} = r$ for some $n_r > 1$
Content: Let R be a commutative ring with an identity such that for all $r\in$ R , there exists some $n>1$ such that $r^n = r$. Show that any prime ideal is  maximal. (Atiyah and MacDonald, Introduction to Commutative Algebra , Chapter 1, Exercise 7.) Any hints?
AcceptedAnswer: Hint: Reduce to the case that $R$ is an integral domain satisfying $\forall r \exists n (r^n=r)$, and show that $R$ is a field.
